dialogs.original: Now, noble peers. the cause why we are metIs to determine of the coronation.In Gods name, speak. When is the royal day?
dialogs.translated: Now, noble peers, we are meeting today to come to a decision about the coronation. In God's name, speak. When will the royal day be?

dialogs.original: Is all things ready for the royal time?
dialogs.translated: Is everything ready for the royal event?

dialogs.original: It is, and wants but nomination.
dialogs.translated: Yes, and all we need to do is name the day.

dialogs.original: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.
dialogs.translated: Then I think tomorrow should be a favorable day.

dialogs.original: Who knows the Lord Protectors mind herein?Who is most inward with the noble duke?
dialogs.translated: Who knows what the Lord Protector Richard thinks about this? Who is closest to the noble duke?

dialogs.original: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
dialogs.translated: We think you would best know his mind, your Grace.

dialogs.original: We know each others faces; for our hearts,    He knows no more of mine than I of yours,    Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.    Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.
dialogs.translated: We know each other's faces. But as for our hearts, he doesn't know mine any more than I know yours or his, or you know mine.

dialogs.original: I thank his Grace. I know he loves me well.    But for his purpose in the coronation,    I have not sounded him, nor he delivered    His gracious pleasure any way therein.    But you, my honorable lords, may name the time,    And in the dukes behalf Ill give my voice,    Which I presume hell take in gentle part.
dialogs.translated: I thank you for saying that. I know he loves me well. But I haven't asked him out about the coronation, and he hasn't told me his preferences about it. But you can name a time, my honorable lords. And I'll give my vote on the duke's behalf. I'm sure he won't mind.

dialogs.original: In happy time here comes the duke himself.
dialogs.translated: Here comes the duke himself, right on time.

dialogs.original: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.    I have been long a sleeper; but I trust    My absence doth neglect no great design    Which by my presence might have been concluded.
dialogs.translated: Good morning, my noble lords and kinsmen. I slept late, but I trust that my absence hasn't delayed any important decisions that required me to be here.

dialogs.original: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord,William Lord Hastings had pronounced your partI mean your voice for crowning of the king.
dialogs.translated: My lord, if you hadn't shown up when you did, Lord Hastings would have taken your part. He was going to cast a vote on your behalf in deciding about the coronation of the king.

dialogs.original: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.    His Lordship knows me well, and loves me well.    My lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborn    I saw good strawberries in your garden there;    I do beseech you, send for some of them.
dialogs.translated: There's no man bolder than Lord Hastings. He knows me well, and loves me well.

dialogs.original: Marry and will, my lord, with all my heart.
dialogs.translated: Indeed, I will do so with pleasure, my lord.

dialogs.original: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.     [they move aside]     Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business    And finds the testy gentleman so hot    As he will lose his head ere give consent    His masters child, as worshipfully he terms it,    Shall lose the royalty of Englands throne.
dialogs.translated: Cousin Buckingham, a word with you. [They move aside and speak so the others can't hear] Catesby has sounded Hastings about our business, and he found the quick-tempered gentleman to be so passionately opposed to our plan thatas Hastings devotedly put ithe would lose his head before he'd allow his master's child to lose the throne of England.

dialogs.original: Withdraw yourself awhile. Ill go with you.
dialogs.translated: Go to the next room for a while. I'll go with you.

dialogs.original: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.    Tomorrow, in my judgement, is too sudden,    For I myself am not so well provided    As else I would be, were the day prolonged.
dialogs.translated: We haven't yet set the date for the triumphant coronation day. In my opinion, tomorrow is too sudden, for I myself am not as well prepared as I would be if a later date were set.

dialogs.original: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?I have sent for these strawberries.
dialogs.translated: Where is my lord the Duke of Gloucester? I've sent for those strawberries.

dialogs.original: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.    Theres some conceit or other likes him well    When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.    I think theres never a man in Christendom    Can lesser hide his love or hate than he,    For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
dialogs.translated: His Grace Richard looks so cheerful and calm this morning. He has some idea or plan that he's pleased about whenever he says "good morning" with such spirit. I don't think there's a man in all the Christian kingdoms who's worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard is. You can know his heart from looking at his face.

dialogs.original: What of his heart perceive you in his face By any livelihood he showed today?
dialogs.translated: And what do you see in his heart today, based on the cheer in his face?

dialogs.original: Marry, that with no man here he is offended,For were he, he had shown it in his looks.
dialogs.translated: That he's not offended with any man here. If he were, he would have shown it in his face.

dialogs.original: I pray God he be not, I say.
dialogs.translated: I pray to God that you're right.

dialogs.original: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve    That do conspire my death with devilish plots    Of damnèd witchcraft,   and that have prevailed    Upon my body with their hellish charms?
dialogs.translated: Please tell me, what is the proper punishment for someone who conspires to kill me with wicked plots and witchcraftand who has already plagued my body with hellish magic?

dialogs.original: The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord,    Makes me most forward in this princely presence    To doom th' offenders, whosoe'er they be.    I say, my lord, they have deservèd death.
dialogs.translated: My love for your Grace makes me say forcefully among all these lords that the offenders should be executed. My lord, they deserve death.

dialogs.original: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.     [shows his arm]     Look how I am bewitched! Behold mine arm    Is like a blasted sapling withered up;    And this is Edwards wife, that monstrous witch,    Consorted with that harlot, strumpet Shore,    That by their witchcraft thus have markèd me.
dialogs.translated: Then let your eyes be the witness of their evil. [He shows his arm] See how I am bewitched! Look at how my arm has shriveled up like a withered tree branch. This is the work of King Edward's wife Elizabeththat monstrous witchand her associate, that whorish Jane Shore. They've done this to me with their witchcraft.

dialogs.original: If they have done this deed, my noble lord
dialogs.translated: If they have done this, my noble lord

dialogs.original: If? Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet,    Talkst thou to me of ifs? Thou art a traitor    Off with his head. Now by Saint Paul I swear    I will not dine until I see the same.    Lovell and Ratcliffe, look that it be done.    The rest that love me, rise and follow me.
dialogs.translated: "If?" You protector of that damned whore, are you talking to me about "ifs?" You are a traitor. Off with his head. By Saint Paul, I swear I won't eat until I see him dead.

dialogs.original: Woe, woe for England! Not a whit for me,    For I, too fond, might have prevented this.    Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm,    And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.    Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble,    And started when he looked upon the Tower,    As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.    O, now I need the priest that spake to me!    I now repent I told the pursuivant,    As too triumphing, how mine enemies    Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered,    And I myself secure in grace and favor.    O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse    Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
dialogs.translated: Woe, woe for England! I pity her fate, but save no pity for myself. I might have prevented this, but I was too foolish. Stanley dreamed that the boar cut off his head, and I laughed at him and refused to flee. Three times today my horse stumbled, and he bucked when he looked upon the Toweras if reluctant to carry me to the slaughterhouse. Oh, now I need that priest I spoke to earlier! And now I regret boasting to the pursuivant that my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I was safe and secure. Oh, Margaret, Margaret, now your heavy curse has fallen on poor Hastings' wretched head!

dialogs.original: Come, come, dispatch. The duke would be at dinner. Make a short shrift. He longs to see your head.
dialogs.translated: Come, come, that's enough. The duke wants to eat his dinner. Make a quick confession. He's eager to see your head.

dialogs.original: O momentary grace of mortal men,    Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!    Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks    Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,    Ready with every nod to tumble down    Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
dialogs.translated: Oh, why do we spend so much time hunting for the temporary approval of mortal men, instead of seeking God's favor? Anyone who builds his hopes on the airy foundation of mankind's approval must live like a drunken sailor on the ship's mastready with every nod of his head to tumble down into the fatal ocean.

dialogs.original: Come, come, dispatch. 'Tis bootless to exclaim.
dialogs.translated: Come on, that's enough. It's useless to make speeches.

dialogs.original: O bloody Richard! Miserable England,    I prophesy the fearfullst time to thee    That ever wretched age hath looked upon.    Come, lead me to the block. Bear him my head.    They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
dialogs.translated: Oh, bloody Richard! Miserable England, I predict that the most frightening time you've ever seen is coming.
